Award.AwardTitle: Dimensions: Collaborative Research: Symbiont and Transcriptomic Niche Dimensions of Long-term Coexistence in Trifolium Communities
Award.AbstractNarration:
Understanding how species coexist, and the role of genetic diversity within and between species, remains a fundamental challenge in biodiversity research. This project focuses on highly diverse communities of clover plants and their bacterial nitrogen-fixing symbionts, rhizobia. Integrating observational approaches, manipulative field, greenhouse, and growth chamber experiments, genomic techniques and phylogenetic analyses, this project will test the importance of rhizobial symbionts and soil feedbacks in coexistence. Gene expression and functional traits will serve as proxies for the ecological niche; this project will determine how these evolve using phylogenetic trees that capture the evolutionary history of species. This project will yield an integrated insight into the molecular, functional, and ecological mechanisms of diversity maintenance and will greatly increase our understanding of biological nitrogen fixation, a critical function of legumes and rhizobia in natural and agricultural ecosystems.

Symbiotic nitrogen fixation has global importance on par with photosynthesis, and this project will assess its functionality in light of genetic variation in symbionts and clover species. This project will train two post-docs and two graduate students and will provide research experiences to undergraduate students through the Plant Genomics at MSU program, and through an exchange program with Howard University at UC Davis. The project will train students in the High School Honors Science Program at MSU and in the Ecological Society of America?s SEEDS program (Strategies for Ecology Education, Diversity and Sustainability: Diverse People for a Diverse Science).

ProgramReference.Text: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project goal is to integrate microbial ecology and host-symbiont interactions into community ecology processes, specifically asking how symbiotic nitrogen-fixing rhizobia impact plant traits, competition, and coexistence. We established thirty focal plots at Bodega Marine Reserve containing 8 annual native Trifolium species for species' abundance surveys, soil sampling, and fine-scale sampling of host-associated microbial communities (2015-2020 annual surveys and sampling). This project focuses on how feedbacks between hosts and their rhizobial and whole-soil communities impacts equalizing and stabilizing processes underling host coexistence. We have found that rhizobial identity impacts these processes, and that plant competition measured in the lab only predicts field co-occurrence when congeneric strains are present, i.e., the scenario that a species would experience when recovering from low density. Inoculation with soil microbial fractions similarly shows that complex communities shift competitive interactions in ways predicted to enhance coexistence. By sequencing individual nodules from greenhouse plantings, we find that Trifolium species associate differently with non-rhizobial nodule-associated bacteria. We characterized the root transcriptome of one species under varying competitive regimes, which implicates both biotic and abiotic components of the niche. We are generating field soil, rhizosphere, and root/nodule microbial community data to test whether hosts alter community composition. We have isolated >800 rhizobial strains from field-collected nodules and have sequenced ~200 of their genomes. Our strains are likely a new species of Rhizobium and only 91% genomically similar to described Rhizobium. Single strain greenhouse experiments show that host species vary in their rhizobial specialization and that rhizobia strains vary in their effects on plant traits, primarily root traits and flowering time. The project also generated genome resources for the 8 native Trifolium species. In addition to providing fundamental knowledge on variation in biological nitrogen fixation in diverse wild plant clades, this understudied group includes important crop inoculants and potential novel cover/forage crops and the project thus could have applied relevance. The project has contributed to training 4 postdocs, 4 grad students, 6 technicians, 13 undergraduates, 8 REU students and 1 high school student and resulted in 12 publications to date along with dozens of poster and oral presentations by project personnel.


Last Modified: 04/21/2021
Modified by: Maren L Friesen

    Maren Friesen
    Public Domain
    Maren L Friesen
    Surveying Bodega Clover
